hints_html:
What does it mean for the matrix to have rank 2? How can the row-echelon form help you?

For a rank 2 matrix in row-echelon form, the first two rows must each have at least 1 non-zero entry, while the last row must consist of zeros only.

question: A 04
sols_html:
__NOTOC__ We reduce the matrix to row-echelon form. Subtracting the first row from the last row transforms

\[\begin{aligned} M = \begin{bmatrix} 1 & 7 & 3 \\ 0 & p & 5 \\ 1 & pq + 7 & 8 \end{bmatrix}\end{aligned}\]

into

\[\begin{aligned} \begin{bmatrix} 1 & 7 & 3 \\ 0 & p & 5 \\ 0 & pq & 5 \end{bmatrix}.\end{aligned}\]

Now, subtracting the second row from the third row yields

\[\begin{aligned} \begin{bmatrix} 1 & 7 & 3 \\ 0 & p & 5 \\ 0 & pq-p & 0 \end{bmatrix}\end{aligned}\]

This matrix either has rank 2 or rank 3. If pq - p=p(q - 1) = 0, then M has rank 2; otherwise, M has rank 3. In other words, M has rank 2 exactly when p=0 or q=1.
sols_raw:
__NOTOC__
We reduce the matrix to row-echelon form.  Subtracting the first row from the last row transforms

:<math> 
M = \begin{bmatrix}  1 & 7 & 3 \\ 0 & p & 5 \\ 1 & pq + 7 & 8 \end{bmatrix}
</math>

into 

:<math> 
\begin{bmatrix}  1 & 7 & 3 \\ 0 & p & 5 \\ 0 & pq  & 5 \end{bmatrix}.
</math>

Now, subtracting the second row from the third row yields

:<math> 
\begin{bmatrix}  1 & 7 & 3 \\ 0 & p & 5 \\ 0 & pq-p  & 0 \end{bmatrix}
</math>
<!-- 
Next a row swap or rows 2 and 3 gives

<math> 
\begin{bmatrix}  1 & 7 & 3 \\  0 & p(q-1)  & 0\\ 0 & p & 5 \end{bmatrix}.
</math>
-->

This matrix either has rank 2 or rank 3. If ''pq - p=p(q - 1) = 0'', then ''M'' has rank 2; otherwise, ''M'' has rank 3. In other words, ''M'' has rank 2 exactly when ''p=0'' or ''q=1''.

<!-- 

== Case 1: ''p = 0'' ==

If ''p'' is 0, then the row reduced echelon form is
<math> 
\begin{bmatrix}  1 & 7 & 3 \\  0 & 0 & 0\\ 0 & 0 & 5 \end{bmatrix}
</math> which has rank 2. Since ''q'' does no longer show up in the matrix, this holds for any value of ''q''.

== Case 2: ''p &ne; 0'' ==

In this case, divide the second row by ''p'' to get

<math> 
\begin{bmatrix}  1 & 7 & 3 \\  0 & q-1 & 0\\ 0 & p & 5 \end{bmatrix}
</math>

=== Case 2a: ''p &ne; 0'', ''q = 1'' ===

In this case, the matrix simplifies to
<math> 
\begin{bmatrix}  1 & 7 & 3 \\  0 & 0 & 0\\ 0 & p & 5 \end{bmatrix}
</math> which has rank 2.

=== Case 2b: ''p &ne; 0'', ''q &ne; 1'' ===

This allows us to divide the second row by ''q-1'' to get

<math> 
\begin{bmatrix}  1 & 7 & 3 \\  0 & 1 & 0\\ 0 & p & 5 \end{bmatrix}
</math>

Row-reducing from here gives

<math> 
\begin{bmatrix}  1 & 7 & 3 \\  0 & 1 & 0\\ 0 & 0 & 5 \end{bmatrix}
</math>

and has rank 3.

To summarize, the matrix ''M'' has rank 2 if either ''p = 0'' '''or''' ''q = 1''.
-->
